displayed_text: Patient: Mmm, hmm. Doctor: Then, I will be able to space it further and further apart. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But the first two or three months are going to be somewhat critical. Patient: The same what we did with the Casodex? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Okay? Patient: Alright. Doctor: Alright. Patient: No problem. Doctor: But, I cannot be putting you on medications and then leaving you with whatever you’re dealing with. Okay. Just like that.

Patient: But that’s a pretty significant consideration. Doctor: Yes oh absolutely and you know you have the exact indication for requiring Xtandi now. My concern is is it worth it because the Xtandi really did take us too far in terms of giving you control from the cancer. So honestly for the Lynparza I would really push for getting the Lynparza… Patient: The Lynparza is the uh inhibitor? Doctor: Is the pills. The PARP inhibitor. Yes. For the BRCA mutation. Patient: And without the Xtandi? Doctor: Correct. Patient: So you would just give up on the Xtandi and just go with the PARP inhibitor? Doctor: And you know if we were going to do the Xtandi base treatment still then we would have to – I would say we need to combine it with something else and that something else could be the BET1 inhibitor. Patient: Is there a third option you said? Doctor: Well the third option is going to chemotherapy. That is definitely an option. I’m not favoring that right off the bat just now. Okay. Patient: We would do that as a last resort? Doctor: Well yeah. I mean not quite last resort. I’m not sure I want to wait (nervous laughter)
